ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to solve differential equation
How to think about, categorize, and solve differential equations.

This is a computational math class. First two thirds of class was learning various techniques to solve first and second order ordinary differential equations (ODEs). We learned about existence and uniqueness theorems. At the end, we discussed at a high level how solving differential equations of higher orders work and how power series and linear algebra can be used to solve some types of ODE systems.
How to solve various forms of ODE as well as some theorems associated with them
I learned different methods to solve first-and-second-order differential equations, as well as linear higher-order different equations.
A good grasp of simple ordinary differential equations.
I learned how to solve certain ordinary differential equations.
very deep, rigorous mathematics with emphasis on theory over simply application.
Problem solving techniques for first-order, higher-order, and systems of differential equations
First order ODEs, second order linear ODEs, a bit about linear higher order ODEs and a little bit about their applications.
I was able to develop a well-roused understanding of the importance of differential equations in their physical applications, specifically how they are utilized in physics and astronomy.
I learned multiple techniques for solving differential equations, as well as the uniqueness and existence theorem.

This class was (as far as straight math courses go at Yale!) honestly very enjoyable for me. Professor Gopal clearly cares a lot about the material he teaches, and was very accessible in his office hours. The textbook we use is also extremely clear--reading it was very helpful for when I needed to review a concept!

It's probably worth mentioning that the class did not have TAs/TFs this semester. Professor Gopal was always accessible and he did review all of the necessary info for midterms and the final, but it's probably going to be important to have a few friends to check pset answers / go over concepts with if the class does not have TAs again.
Developed basic understanding of how to solve simple ODEs...

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Having practice exams before the exams wouldve made students feel more confident going into exams

I thought the class was very well-taught; lectures were at just the right speed, and I was able to follow quite well. However, there were no posted lecture notes and classes weren't recorded, so missing a lecture can be really difficult to recover from. Posting lecture notes would have been really helpful. Additionally, there was only one problem set after the second midterm, no practice problems posted before the final, and no office hours to ask for any, so for a good portion of the content on the final, it was the first time we had ever attempted a problem on that topic. I would have appreciated practice problems on these later topics.

Strengths: creative exams, problem sets that helped learn material
Weaknesses: not recorded

I think we covered a lot of contents and they are well communicated. However, it would be nice if there are materials that help us learn the things we didn't quite catch in class. We only have pset posted on canvas, no notes, recorded lectures, pset/exam solutions or anything. We went into the final exam with no practice materials on half of the topics. The exams are also a lot harder than the psets, since it tests a lot of theories and have those mega-problems that really pushes you to synthesize everything you learned. It's nice and helpful for learning, but not under the time pressure.

The lectures were always very engaging, and the psets were quite reasonable. I thought the exams were also fair, with somewhat tricky final problems. More practice with the concepts we covered in the last couple weeks of class- series solutions at regular singular points and linear systems of ODEs- would have been helpful. It felt a bit unfair that the final exam asked about these late-semester topics that we had never practiced on a pset.

Good teacher, taught following the book and psets/tests were very fair. A huge method of improvement would be the availability of resources online/in person. Need a TA. Would be good to record lecture/post lecture notes and tell class which chapters explicitly will be covered on the test. Would be good also to post practice exams/solutions and keep the canvas up-to-date.
The course was informative and followed a natural progression.

strengths: good introduction to higher level, difficult math

weaknesses: required tons of textbook supplementation, exams were on content not covered in class, lack of examples provided in lecture

Strengths: Phenomenal course taught by a professor that brings in his own research as an example of the topic's application. Highly interaction-based course with great feedback provided on all homeworks and exams.
Weaknesses: None

strengths: problem sets and tests align with what comes up on tests

weaknesses: sometimes the material is covered a little too quickly
I loved it!!
I think that having more office hours or TAs could be helpful

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, it was great.

I'd recommend it if you are specifically interested in the subject. It's not a proof-based course, and honestly the calculus is almost always really easy, so the main thing that would deter someone from taking it is just interest.
Yes, the class is pretty well-structured and it taught me what I need to know for physics.

Overall, MATH 246 was decent and I would recommend it if needed for major or prereq but temper your expectations with the fact that its hard for differential equations as a topic to be super exciting. The textbook was used as the primary resource and Abi pretty much taught straight out of it. Lectures were not recorded. The workload was moderate, about a 3.5 out of 5 in terms of difficulty and time commitment. The teaching style was decent, but perhaps a bit dry and not as engaging as some other classes I have taken. The problem sets were a mix of useful exercises that helped to solidify the concepts covered in class and some busy work where we would need to do multiple problems per technique. We had 8 problem sets, roughly one every week and a half, with the later ones taking between 7-10 hours each. Prof. Abi is a legit math guy and knows his stuff. The exams were creative and tested problem-solving skills. The exams were designed to see how well students could apply concepts learned in class to new and unique situations. This means you could not get by with just memorization and plug-and-chug. We had 2 midterms and 1 exam. Prof. Abi said he tries to have half the class get A- or A.

I may be biased, because I was taking this class as a easy gut due to its low courseload rating. But this class taken with Abi is not an easy class! This ended up being my most stressful class. However, he pushes you to really understand the material, and we covered much more contents than when other professors have taught it. Take it with Abi if you are really interested.
Absolutely, especially if it is taught again by Abi. ODEs are a fun, fairly straightforward topic within higher-level math.
yes only if they have a specified need/ desire to learn the topic (ODEs)
I would recommend this to another student if they think the material will be valuable.
It was really interesting, and  Abi taught it very well.
only if necessary for major (math, engineering). Otherwise, unnecessarily difficult and theoretical.

If you have to take differential equations, I would say take it with Abi. This course was certainly hard, but I found it very interesting and it made me actually want to undertake the relatively arduous task of differential equations. Most of the psets, with the exception of one or two, were fairly reasonable.
Yes!
Yes I most absolutely would! It has the perfect balance of proofs and application-based material to keep the engagement of the course very high.
only take it if you need it for your major
Yes
With the selection of professors this year, I think this class was definitely the best of the three differential equations classes offered. If Gopal teaches it again, I would recommend :)
